questions.question_text: A network switch was installed to provide connectivity to cameras monitoring wildlife in a remote location. The organization is concerned that intruders could potentially leverage unattended equipment in the remote location to connect rogue devices and gain access to the organization's resources. Which of the following techniques would BEST address the concern?

choices.C: Activate PoE+ on the active switchports.
choices.A: Configure port security using MAC filtering.
choices.D: Disable Neighbor Discovery Protocol on the switch.
choices.B: Manually register the cameras on the switch address table.

discussion.content: But could the bad actor not just spoof his MAC address?
Why not: B. Manually register the cameras on the switch address table. ?

comments.content: You would not be preventing attackers from connecting

discussion.content: I would have done Zero trust config because MAC filtering is not a good security.

Selected Answer: A
A. Configure port security using MAC filtering would be the BEST technique to address the concern. Port security can be used to restrict access to an interface by limiting the MAC addresses that are allowed to send packets through the port. By configuring port security with MAC filtering, only the authorized MAC addresses of the cameras will be allowed to send packets through the switch ports, preventing rogue devices from connecting to the organization's resources.

Selected Answer: A
Configure port security using MAC filtering.

Answer is A - Port security
Whitelisted MAC addresses are allowed through any port on the device and blacklisted MAC addresses are blocked on all ports. Other devices, such as Cisco Catalyst switches, support MAC filtering on a port-by-port basis. This is referred to as port security.
It says "BEST". In this case, MAC filtering offers better security. It is essentially D with additional security.
Would it be A or D. It's a tight call. But I'd almost say A. I'll take a look at this one

questions.question_text: A technician is documenting an application that is installed on a server and needs to verify all existing web and database connections to the server. Which of the following tools should the technician use to accomplish this task?

discussion.content:
To verify existing web and database connections to a server, the technician should use:

C. netstat

The netstat (network statistics) command is used to display active network connections, listening ports, and other network-related information on a computer or server. By running netstat, the technician can see a list of established connections, including those associated with web and database services. This information helps in documenting and verifying the current network connections to the server.

GPT picks (C) netstat for these reasons:

"Netstat (short for "network statistics") is a command-line tool that provides information about active network connections and listening ports on a system. It can show you the current network connections, along with information about the local and remote addresses, port numbers, connection status, and more. This information can help you identify which connections are established to the server and what ports are being used for communication.

Options (A) tracert, (B) ipconfig, and (D) nslookup serve different purposes:

Tracert (A) is used to trace the route that packets take to reach a destination, showing each hop along the way.
Ipconfig (B) is used to display IP configuration information for a network interface.
Nslookup (D) is used to query DNS servers to resolve domain names into IP addresses.

None of these alternatives provide the detailed information about existing connections that the technician needs to verify web and database connections to the server"
Of course the netstat -a

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C. netstat.

Netstat is a command-line utility that allows the technician to view active TCP/IP connections and their status. The technician can use the command "netstat -an" to check all existing connections, including web and database connections to the server. This will show the status of the connections, the local and remote IP addresses, and the port numbers being used.

Answer is C: Netstat - The netstat command displays the contents of various network-related data structures for active connections. This netstat function shows the state of all configured interfaces. Keyword here is cpnnections:... "needs to verify all existing web and database connections to the server."

comments.content: Hey Jamber, I do believe that it is the following "to verify all existing web and database connections to the server" after tying the command on a server at work it made sense to me. I hope your studies have been beneficial to you and if you took your exam already hoped you passed :) .

"ipconfig" lists all TCP/IP information and network adapter information of a device. This is where you usually find the IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, DHCP servers, DNS servers, and other network configuration settings.

"netstat" shows all active connections to a device. Because the technician wants to verify all existing web and database connections, netstat will show all active connections.

discussion.content: Can someone highlight the key point inside of the question designating netstat over ipconfig as the answer?

questions.question_text: A technician is assisting a user who cannot access network resources when the workstation is connected to a VoIP phone. The technician identifies the phone as faulty and replaces it. According to troubleshooting methodology, which of the following should the technician do NEXT?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
The correct answer is E. Verify functionality.

According to troubleshooting methodology, after identifying the faulty VoIP phone and replacing it, the technician should verify that the issue has been resolved by testing the workstation's access to network resources. This step is known as "Verifying Full System Functionality" or "Verifying the solution has been properly implemented" and it is the next step after implementing the solution.

comments.content: it is 7 steps you left out Implement

discussion.content:
Answer is E: Verify full system functionality and if applicable implement preventative measures.

CompTIA 6-Step Troubleshooting Process:

1. Identify the problem.
2. Establish a theory of probably cause. (Question the obvious)
3. Test the theory to determine cause.
4. Establish a plan of action to resolve the problem and implement the solution.
5. Verify full system functionality and if applicable implement preventative measures.
6. Document findings, actions, and outcomes.
Source: I am A+ Certified.
The key point is "replaces it"
Why not B??
Jamber you confused me so much lol

comments.content: oops, disregard... this was for the previous question.

discussion.content: Can someone highlight the key point inside of the question designating netstat over ipconfig as the answer?

questions.question_text: Which of the following OSI model layers contains IP headers?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D. Network

The OSI model is a conceptual framework that helps to understand how different protocols and technologies work together to enable communication between devices. In this model, the Network layer is responsible for routing and addressing, which includes the use of IP (Internet Protocol) headers. IP headers contain information about the source and destination of a packet, as well as other parameters used for routing and fragmentation.

Selected Answer: D
Internet Protocol header (IP header)
Fields in a datagram used to identify 
source and destination IP addresses, 
protocol type, and other layer 3 
properties

Selected Answer: D
GPT says The Network layer (Layer 3) of the OSI model is responsible for routing and addressing, and it includes the IP (Internet Protocol) headers. The IP headers contain important information such as source and destination IP addresses, time-to-live (TTL), and more, which are essential for routing packets across networks.

Answer is D: (Network) Layer 3
The Internet Layer of the TCP/IP model aligns with the Layer 3 (Network) layer of the OSI model. This is where IP addresses and routing live.

questions.question_text: A small office is running WiFi 4 APs, and neighboring offices do not want to increase the throughput to associated devices. Which of the following is the MOST cost-efficient way for the office to increase network performance?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
They do not want to increase the throughput to associated devices. So no channel bonding. Most COST effective solution is to disable 2.4ghz and use 5.0. Wifi is 802.11n which used 2.4 and 5.0. This has no cost to this solution.

comments.content: Because WiFi 4 is dual band; it has both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz frequency.
however, you will have devices that are not compatible with 5ghz, so disabling 2.4ghz isnt the right play
In reality, sure you're right. But you have to answer these questions using CompTIA's logic.
Because 802.11n uses both 2.4 and 5.0. Disabling 2.4 will ensure only 5.0 is transmitting
How can it possibly not cost money to go from 2.4ghz to 5ghz?
By enabling channel bonding, the office can increase the data rate of its WiFi network to 108 Mbps, which can provide a significant boost in performance.

discussion.content: Channel bonding combines multiple channels—or lanes—to increase the amount of traffic that a modem's highway can comfortably support.

Selected Answer: C
In most cases you can not manage neighbouring's network. The whole idea is that the neighbour will not increase the throughput does NOT mean your own network can not increase to counter it. B is not the correct answer as you run into scenario where 5G will decrease the area of coverage for some devices and also potential devices not supported by 5G. 

So C is the most likely answer as you can channel bond and increase YOUR OWN throughput.

Selected Answer: C
We dont have to do anything with neighboring offices. statement "neigboring offices do not want to increase their throughput" means they dont want to do anything to their existing setup.
Read question without caring for neighboring offices and choose best answer to increase your small office wifi performance.
wifi 4 has 2.4 & 5 spectrums but enabling channel bonding will increase performance.

Selected Answer: C
The most cost-efficient way for a small office running WiFi 4 Access Points (APs) to increase network performance, without increasing the throughput to associated devices, is:

C. Enable channel bonding

Channel bonding allows two channels within the same frequency band to be combined to increase throughput and network performance. This can be a cost-effective solution because it doesn’t require purchasing new hardware and can be configured on existing APs

Selected Answer: B
Keywords : " do not want to increase the throughput"
Channel bonding increases throughput. With that being said, disabling the 2.4ghz will increase performance as they will all use 5ghz instead

Selected Answer: B
"Channel bonding is a networking technique that combines multiple communication channels or pathways to INCREASE the overall bandwidth and THROUGHPUT."

"Channel bonding is employed in Wi-Fi networks to INCREASE the data THROUGHPUT for wireless devices"

"Channel Bonding is a technique used in data communication that involves combining multiple network connections or channels into a single logical connection. This results in INCREASED network THROUGHPUT"

Ok, now that THAT'S done, the question very explicitly states "neighboring offices DO NOT want to INCREASE the THROUGHPUT..."

The answer CANNOT be C.

Selected Answer: B
B. Disable the 2.4GHz radios.

Disabling the 2.4GHz radios would likely be the most cost-efficient solution because it does not involve purchasing new hardware or upgrading existing infrastructure. By disabling the 2.4GHz radios, the network would operate solely on the 5GHz band, which typically experiences less interference and congestion compared to the 2.4GHz band. This could potentially improve network performance for devices that support 5GHz connectivity without incurring additional costs.

Selected Answer: B
Ok, so I think this is more about the "NEIGBORING OFFICES" portion. I don't disagree with the channel bonding assessment, but this feels like either CompTIA is throwing in a red herring, or they are pointing you towards an answer with this detail. So I am gonna say B. Disabling 2.4Ghz.

This is more of a listening to test writers prompting the correct direction than it is base level factual knowledge. So good luck everyone, hope this isn't on our test cause it looks like BS

Selected Answer: B
To assist with the issue and prevent any interruption in the neighboring offices, removing the 2.4GHz lanes are the best option. It will take care of both points mentioned.

Selected Answer: B
B for sure

Selected Answer: C
The most cost-efficient way to increase network performance in this scenario would likely be:

C. Enable channel bonding.

Channel bonding involves combining multiple adjacent channels into a single, wider channel. This can increase the overall data transfer rate and improve network performance. It's a more cost-effective option compared to adding another AP or upgrading to WiFi 5, as enabling channel bonding can be done through configuration changes on the existing equipment.

Selected Answer: C
Wireless N supports the use of multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) technology to use multiple antennas to transmit and receive data at higher speeds. Wireless N supports channel bonding by combining two 20 MHz channels into a single 40 MHz channel to provide additional bandwidth.

Selected Answer: C
NIC teaming Two or more NIC 
aggregated into a single channel link 
for fault tolerance and increased 
throughput. Also known as NIC bonding
Channel bonding is a wireless networking technique that combines channels to increase bandwidth.

Selected Answer: D
While channel bonding can increase throughput, it may also increase interference for neighboring offices and is not as cost-effective as simply upgrading to WiFi 5.

Upgrading to WiFi 5 is a cost-effective way to improve network performance within the existing infrastructure, benefiting from the enhancements and efficiencies of the newer standard. However, it's important to ensure that client devices are compatible with WiFi 5 for the best results.

Selected Answer: C
Answer: C is correct.

Going back to the Core 1 book: 
 "The 802.11n standard allows two adjacent 20 MHz channels to be combined into
a single 40 MHz channel, referred to as “channel bonding.” Due to the restricted channel layout of 2.4 GHz, on a network with multiple APs, channel bonding is a practical option only in the 5 GHz band.".

So in short, the best answer is channel bonding which would require you to change your channel to 5ghz regardless. This would give you increased reliability.

Selected Answer: B
The 2.4GHz frequency band is often crowded and subject to interference from neighboring networks and devices, which can negatively impact network performance. By disabling the 2.4GHz radios and focusing solely on the 5GHz frequency band, the network can potentially experience better performance and reduced interference, which aligns with the goal of increasing network performance in a cost-efficient manner.

Enabling channel bonding (option C) can indeed be a valid consideration to increase network performance. Channel bonding involves combining multiple adjacent channels in the 2.4GHz or 5GHz frequency bands to increase the available bandwidth, which can lead to improved data rates and throughput.

Enabling channel bonding can be a cost-efficient way to enhance network performance, especially if the neighboring offices do not object to increased throughput. However, it's worth noting that while channel bonding can provide benefits, it might also introduce higher potential for interference in congested environments, particularly if not managed properly.

GPT nails the only answer:
"The MOST cost-efficient way for the office to increase network performance in this scenario would be to (B) Disable the 2.4GHz radios.

Disabling the 2.4GHz radios on the existing WiFi 4 access points can help improve network performance because the 2.4GHz band is more susceptible to interference from neighboring WiFi networks and other devices. By focusing on the 5GHz band, which usually offers more channels and less interference, the office can potentially achieve better throughput and stability without adding extra APs or upgrading to WiFi 5.

Option (A) Adding another AP, (C) Enabling channel bonding, and (D) Upgrading to WiFi 5 might provide performance improvements but could also involve higher costs and more complex configurations. Disabling the 2.4GHz radios is a simpler and cost-effective step to enhance network performance in the current setup."

Selected Answer: C
The most cost-efficient way to increase network performance in this case is to enable channel bonding. Channel bonding is a technique that combines two or more adjacent Wi-Fi channels into a single, wider channel. This increases the amount of data that can be transmitted at once, and can improve performance significantly.

Upgrading to WiFi 5 would also increase performance, but it would be more expensive than enabling channel bonding. Additionally, it is not clear whether the neighboring offices would be willing to upgrade their equipment to support WiFi 5.

Adding another AP would not necessarily increase performance, as it could lead to congestion on the network. Disabling the 2.4GHz radios would reduce interference, but it would also reduce the number of devices that could connect to the network.

Selected Answer: C
The MOST cost-efficient way for the office to increase network performance in this scenario would be to enable channel bonding.

Channel bonding combines multiple channels to increase the overall bandwidth available to clients, which can improve network performance without requiring the purchase of additional hardware or upgrading to a new WiFi standard.

Selected Answer: C
Enabling channel bonding can be the cheapest way for the office to increase network performance. This approach combines two adjacent channels, effectively doubling the bandwidth available for devices. Upgrading to WiFi 5 or adding another AP might result in higher costs, and disabling the 2.4GHz radios would limit the number of devices that could connect to the network.

Selected Answer: D
WiFi 5 (also known as IEEE 802.11ac) is the latest version of the WiFi standard, and it provides significantly faster speeds and greater coverage compared to previous versions such as WiFi 4 (IEEE 802.11n). Upgrading to WiFi 5 would be the most cost-efficient way for the small office to increase network performance.

Latest is wifi 6 802.11ax.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is C: 
Channel bonding is a practice commonly used in IEEE 802.11 implementations in which two adjacent channels within a given frequency band are combined to increase throughput between two or more wireless devices.
Channel bonding is also known as Ethernet bonding, but it is used heavily in Wi-Fi implementations. It has become a very popular technique in the world of Wi-Fi because its increased throughput provides for more functionality within Wi-Fi deployments.
Channel bonding is also known as NIC bonding.
Source- https://www.techopedia.com/definition/2999/channel-bonding

comments.content: Hi kungfuseven, since Channel bonding increases throughput, this would not be the correct answer, the office DOES NOT want to increase throughput to the associated devices, hence why option B would be correct and more cost effective.
